P.FONT: Interesting trance-y work - sounds like the beginning of a journey, and the background noises help counterpoint the main beat without distracting from it - a nice, synergistic piece of electronica.

Nice rhythm, except it sounds a bit too much like a cheap midi construct. The animal hooting in the background doesn't really seem to fit the bosa-nova feel of the track. In terms of 'rightness', the background sound feels tacked on.

I would de-emphasize the background sounds in the first track, pulling the repetitive beat to the forefront. I would try to find the regular beat in the target - the high 'vibraphone' sounding note, and synchronise it to the final high note in source 1's repeating beat. Because the target has such a different rhythm to the source, I would attempt to marry the regular beat in the source and target, not the main beat of the source to the main rhythm of the target. Once they were synced, I would try to slip the bosanova rhythm over the top of the conjoined beats. Again, the background hoots of the target would not feature during the transition.
I have no background in music other than being an avid fan...
The bosanova rhythm makes it harder to match the more regular beat of the source. However, by identifiying the regular beat in the target, I think it should be possible to make a pleasant transition.
The least coherent point was at 10 seconds.
The central part of the transition (specifically from 10 to 14 seconds) was a bit too chaotic and sounded automated.
The effective transition response, or indication that a transition was taking place, was at 7 seconds. Notably, with repeated listenings, the transition sounded smoother.
Notice that a change is foreshadowed in the music
Sounds to me like the most important structural beat (the bass note) of the target is being introduced here.
Discordant, jarred out of the listening process
sounded like incompatible beats were mixed
Slightly less discordant, but too busy
Sounded like several instruments were competing for my attention
Felt the transition was complete
The source felt removed now and that we were entirely in the target

Acceptable to both, yes. Palatable to Live electronic show yes. Palatable to a Computer game: maybe. At a live electronic show, some expectation of mismatching is expected, but in a game, where all the mixing is presumed to have been done prior to release, any discordant mix would be noticed. In a game, the discordant mix would be acceptable if the player was aware that the music was being played in reaction to the game state (eg. transitioning from wandering around to combat). Again, the more you listen to the morph, the less problematic it sounds.

I would pull some of the complexity out of the 10 and 14 second bars. The 'sawing' background sound of the source is what I believe is interfering at the 10 second mark. I would fade it out a lot quicker, since it is only background and superfluous to the beat. I would fade the vibraphone in a little later to avoid my perceived interference with the background bass string and the vibraphone at the 14 second mark.
I would refine those two points more. It does not sound like it would take a lot of time.

This morph sounded more planned than the first. There was effective foreshadowing by introducing some of the background noises of the target into the morph early on. Because of the focus on a regular beat, the transition felt like more of an interlude in a music piece, but there was no jarring at all. The quieter transition also helped flag that a change was occurring.

Positive - I could listen to the track transition without ever being jarred out of the listening process. There was no discordance, and at all times the beat and instruments seamlessly transitioned. The use of a strong beat around which the rest of the music was played helped with this morph.
It was an effective morph. By stripping out excessive instruments around the main beat, however, it was a little more empty than the first transtion
A little discordant due to the overlapping background sounds.
The background 'ambient' sounds are a bit messy, but because they don't distract from the main beat, it is not a huge isse. The background vibraphone chord introduces the transtion effectively.
Pleasant expectation of the coming transition.
The transition really begins here, but it is a little too empty, due to the next bar not progressing the transition sufficiently.
This bar almost feels redundant.
As the only new sound introduced here is the crashing cymbals, it feels that the transition is passing too slowly. Jumping straight to the next bar would work better
Completion
This is a very effective and tight kick into the next track. As I said above, it could have been moved forward one bar with no problems.
Acceptable and palatable in both cases. The morph is clean and continuous, and the transition between styles is transparent.

I would drop the sequence from approx 18 seconds through to 21 seconds. This bar does not add enough transitional changes for an aesthetically smooth transition. Although the transition is smooth musically, it feels overly cautious.
I would strip back some of the overlapping background sounds at the 8 second mark back. This overlap is more cacophanous than it needs to be.
Very smooth and relaxed. Warm.
Anxious, repressed and confused, but still rhythmic.
I would pitch the source higher to match the jarring discordance of the target. I would speed it up slowly to get the same anxious mood as the target.
ditto

I would draw on the slowly increasing pitch in the source to highlight the frantic nature of the target. The difference in pace and mood are obvious difficulties, but there are underlying moods that can still be used to create a connection, articulation of the first piece, which is more jazzy in nature. Some of the syncopation of the source could be used to match the target.
This is an excellent piece of transitional music. The mood of the source almost seems a precursor to

Excellent - because of the complexity of the tracks, the highly skillful melding of the source and target was a joy to hear. It was a very deliberate transition in moods, and almost evoked a story in itself as the listener was transported from a relaxed environment with the potential for disaster directly into a schizophrenic soundscape. Very worthwhile.
The smoothness of this track was very important to the effectiveness of the transition, due to the perceived surface differences between the source and target.
First reaction that something is out of the ordinary
Some atypical patterns in the loungy jazz track.
Verification that the transition really is picking up.
The speed of the track is increasing slowly, but due to the smoothness of the transition it is still difficult to determine specific points.
Very cool experimental mash up.
Really complex yet effective mesh of the sounds of the target and source
It's all over - we've descended into madness
The addition of the high pitched sample really conveys the loss of the sanity of the source
Palatable and acceptable. This is an excellent transition between two completely different tracks.
I can't improve on it.
See above.

Another excellent transition, but not as natural as the first. There was a distinct shift up in tempo around the 19 seconds mark, but this composition introduces the 'hyper' notes of the target a little less subtly than the original. In doing so, however, it actually creates a new sound all its own in the middle of the transition, so that instead of transitioning from a source to a target, it actually sounds as though it is transitioning frmo a source to target 1 and then from target 1 to target 2.
There was no experience of a transition - this sounded like one lengthy piece of music that just happened to change stylistically.

My response was favourable, due to the internal consistency of the music throughout the entire transition. There was only one part where the transition felt as though it might have been rushed slightly (19 sec).
Seems out of place - first hint that there is a transition
The jarred introduction of the high-pitched sample indicates that
Bit discordant
The tempo increases with the introduction of this sample and it seems a little too quick.
Excellent
Sounds like an intermediate track - the bass line is an aspect of the target that is difficult to pick out of the target so that when it is isolated it sounds like its own track.
Dancing
The section from 23 to 26 seconds works like a bridge and kicks the second half of the transition off very effectively. No hint that this is not part of either the original source or target.

Yes, to both. Only the introduction of somewhat out of place sounds at 8 and 19 seconds would give them pause (if they were playing a game). The 'bridge' starting at 23 seconds draws the attention away from this other sound, though.
I would halve the length of the sample at 8 sec and 19 sec - the second part of this high pitched sample is the distracting part (sample starts at 8 sec and should end at 9, not 10)

I would attempt to 'fix' the sample at 8 and 19 seconds not by cutting it in half but by changing the strength of the second part, so that it did not distract so much during the transition. The first part of the sample is a good initial introduction to the target, whereas the second part of the sample is 'too' much of the hyper rhythm.
Funky rock piano track. Not particularly exciting but clean and pleasant.
I like this track a lot. Very melancholy/eerie, but without being slow and brooding. It has an interesting energy about it produced by the creepy background riff.

The source is much happier than the target. Twisting some of the bouncy energy of the source piano into the more claustrophobic and tight riff of the target requires subverting the bright sounds. I might try to turn the source piano into the percussion line of the target.
ditto

The mood is more different here than in the previous track, and there is no underlying broodiness that can be exploited in the source, which makes it harder. Also, the density of the target is greater than the source, with a more psychotic energy than the happy riff in the source.

This is an excellent transition. The strings in the background are subverted into the target in a very clever and disconcerting way. I am most impressed by how subtly they are strung into the main riff of the target

The smoothness was critical to my perception of the track, knowing the source and target. The journey of the pieces transition was perfect, and the reweaving of what sounded like three separate melodies was seamless.
The transition effectively turned my happy go lucky mood into a strained, nail biting tension.
Happy go lucky piano is being overtaken by nervousness of the strings.
The strings are part of the background music, but at this point they loop on themselves, which takes the emphasis off the piano and introduces us to a new tune.
Something is going on that is making me forget the piano
The first part of the third rhythm is being introduced, which now begins to hide the piano (or relegates it to a percussive beat)
We're moving into a different space.
More of the baseline is kicking in and really pulling us towards the target.
We've arrived.
The third rhythm now takes over with a staccato introduction, and all memory of the source is gone.
This morph is fine - the transition works seamlessly and is interesting without jarring the listener.
No changes are necessary
See above
This morph focussed on the tenseness of the target, and was less pleasant to listen to. It felt a bit forced, and the tempo increase towards the end of the track was obvious.
Created a level of discomfort
The response was negative, but if that was the intent, then the discontinuity succeeded.
Nice mix of the target sound
The snippets from the target fit here very naturally
Clumsy mix of the source and target
This breaks the timing of the underlying tracks somewhat and is discontinuous for that reason.
Good introduction to the main repeated sample of the target, but the tempo increase seems a bit overt
The tempo increase seems to be too deliberate here.
Nice counterpoint to the sample that started to repeat at 0:17
The mix of two main phrases in the target is excellent and creative (ie. doesn't seem auto generated)

I think it works very effectively, despite what I would at first listen consider a lack of smoothness compared to some of the other tracks. It seems like a more deliberate transition than the first version of this source/target mix.
I would fix the 10-11 second jitter.
I would stretch the tempo increase starting at 17 seconds out a little bit so that it is not such an extreme shift.
Somewhat busy - doesn't feel like there is much direction to this track. Too much sound.
Sounds like game music. Better than the source, but also quite busy, and doesn't have the same intensity of emotion/mood as some of the other tracks.
I would try to merge the baselines. These samples both have a very computer gamey feel, so they should merge nicely. I would attempt to
ditto
The apparent similary of the tracks should make it easier to merge them.

An excellent transition. Very effective in maintaining the feel of the source, and then effortlessly transferring into the target. Unlike other morphs, this one feels like there is a specific cut over point, but it does so very well.
I believe it was directly related. The music itself does not evoke much emotion, as it is very cookie-cutter in its style.
Because of the style of the tracks, the continuity automatically made the morph successful.
Introduction of what sounds like an extension of the existing track, not a new sound.
The first use of samples from the target highlights the coming change.
Drums rise to the foreground briefly here.
There is a drum riff here that further foreshadows the change.
surprised at hearing an effective melody that is unique to the morph.
The track cuts over into a new track target completely with the introduction of the high-pitched pattern that is a very effective merge of the two common instruments (some sort of xylo/vibraphone).
The baseline changes here and it sounds nice.
The final component of the target is merged into the transition here.
Definitely acceptable, due to the smoothness of the transition and stylistic similarly of the source and target.
None
None
Very clean transition. Hard to tell where the music changes, due to the baseline drawing the listeners attention.
It was a very transparent transition. There was only vague, brief moment of discontinuity, at the 6-7 second mark.
The smooth changes were effective in making the transition pleasurable.
Jarred
After repeated listenings the jarredness seems to have disappeared
Nice
Change in the riff being plaed by the main instrument (keyboard?) worked nicely here.
Somewhat clunky
The use of the percussive keyboard here to begin a change in melody wasn't ideal.
Nice
Using the keyboard to play over the baseline is effective here.
Effective and palatable. The transition is smooth enough not to evoke any negative emotions or responses
I would not change the keyboard riff that was played at 12 seconds - in the morph, it changes unnecessarily.
I would try to remove some of the busy sounds pervading the morph.

My musical background is from the consumer side, not the creator side. I love music, especially experimental electronic and genre fusions, such as acid jazz, and listening to some of the source files and how they can be transitioned almost effortlessly was very interesting.
The questionnaire is simply too long for all but the most dedicated :)
2+ hrs
